Thanks for the feedback, I'll get those fixed. A couple of things:
1. Since we don't have numpy to serve as a reference in unit tests, how should this be handled? Is it sufficient to use simple fixed inputs to validate against hand-calculated outputs?
2. I wasn't sure whether some of the util functions (mainly those in detail/fuse.h and detail/extern.h) belong in TVM core rather than TOPI. Let me know if these should be moved

also it is recommended to use rebase and squash flow to fold up your commits, this is not needed but helpful for you to manage things locally.  http://docs.tvmlang.org/how_to/contribute.html#git-workflow-howtos

We can expose things to python for the test, which we have to do eventually. See https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/src/api for some examples. Let us register them as
The general steps are:
- [ ] Add a topi/src/topi.cc to register APIs
- [ ] Register functions under ```topi.xx``` 
- [ ] Add this as TVM extension which allows us to test correctness from python side  
     - Refer to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/apps/extension
It might be helpful to do some API coverage test in cpp, but I will let you be the judge

@masahi the NNVM keras frontend expects NHWC and transforms that automatically to NCHW for TVM. The shape on that line is the same on every other successful test in that file, so I don't think that's the issue. Edit: which backend are you using, llvm / cuda / other?

@tqchen thanks, let me check.

Update: I fixed the argument issue (I think?).

Now each OpenGL argument is categorized as one of the following three:
- Input texture;
- Output texture;
- Uniform value.

This information, together with argument names, need to be stored in some metadata. As a result, the "source" of an OpenGL module is now JSON.

I tested the changed version with `tests/webgl/test_local_save_load.py` and `tests/webgl/test_remote_save_load.py`. The latter is a simple ewise test using RPC with browser.
PR #775 makes this work. Closing the issue!
OK, I will go ahead per your suggestion

The next 2 correctness fixes to work on:

- Reduction axis not yet supported. This must be supported for gemm.
- ThreadIdx extent not utilized. This might lead to writing to out-of-bound elements in an array.
@tqchen I'm just looking at exposing the ops to python, how should the register code be built? should tvm.cc be added to the build for the main tvm lib, or should it build as a separate library?
For now we can build it as a separate library and load it in via ctypes.LoadLibrary https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/apps/extension is a good reference

Relocations in generic ELF (EM: 62) /usr/bin/ld: /tmp/tmpCAA5A7/mylib.o: Relocations in generic ELF (EM: 62) /tmp/tmpCAA5A7/mylib.o: error adding symbols: File in wrong format collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

It is likely due to the fact that you did not set the correct target triple. The default tripe for remote works for raspbery-pi, but not on aarch64 device.
see http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/deployment/cross_compilation_and_rpc.html#run-opencl-kernel-remotely-by-rpc which might gives you an example target triple for aarch64 board

can you do a big investigation into this? We can use pragma debug_skip_region to remove regions in compute and only keep the memory allocation.
We do need to remove the LOG(INFO)s

If it's using the last merged, what is the best way to resolve this? could the Jenkinsfile be modified in a separate PR without breaking the build if libtopi.so is missing?

My understanding of the code is that in [lines 248-251 of schedule_dataflow_rewrite.cc](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/78e00410e5bdf5f4428e39285cac75592233a813/src/schedule/schedule_dataflow_rewrite.cc#L248) we avoid rebasing bound variables. What's the reason? What's the problem if we comment those lines?
FYI, When I comment those lines, the testcase above passes and all TVM's python tests pass, as well.
it is because the thread binding semantics of different scope is not very well defined in this case(are we bind to the rebased one, or the original one as the code indicated)

verified. it fixes the bug under the arch `arm-linux-gnueabihf`. thanks
We can use alloc->extents[0].type() instead, since sometimes Int(32) is enough and most cases we use Int(32) for the space

I am not sure I understood your question.

The for loop in the [Run](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/814b46dccb3c340be7611d113a303a546f7b2b2a/src/runtime/graph/graph_runtime.cc#L52) function calls the packed functions for all layers of final graph.
Each op_exec here corresponding to each node compute.

But one difference here is the operation represented by the packed function op_exec here is a fused (optimized [Ref](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/69f0b75786786121569f25ced29bbff8826c2cc9/python/nnvm/compiler/build_module.py#L251)) version of one or more nodes of original graph before nnvm compilation process.

Siva

thank you very much. @srkreddy1238 
Did you mean the element in op_exec is a operation or a layer? I have other question, how can I get the function name of the std::function<void()> in op_exec[]? the true name of the fuction in op_exec[]
thank you.
jiangyong

@tqchen, I extracted all tensorization feasibility checks that exist in tensorize.cc and I can now run them during my `Stage::autotensorize()` call. In order to perform those checks I need to run the initial passes of lowering, i.e., `Schedule::normalize()` and `Schedule::InferBound()`. Obviously, I don't modify the original schedule.
However, there are still some more checks that are done in `StorageFlattener` that are not in `Stage::autotensorize()`. Specifically, those checks are in `StorageFlattener::HandleBufferBindScope()`, including the ones enforced by `ArgBinder::BindBuffer()` called by `HandleBufferBindScope()`. 
I still don't fully understand `AttrStmt` and how `HandleBufferBindScope()` works. Can you please give me ideas on how to isolate those extra checks? Also are any of those checks dependent on any lowering pass happening before `StorageFlatten()`? 
Thanks!
TVM support symbolic shape, which means it is able to support functions for a dynamic input shape. The support in nnvm is currently lacking and requires high level unrolling to do it.
drop out is simply optimized away for inference.

As suggested by @derisavi-huawei , it would be helpful to improve code by clarifying the questions of interest in the code, so I created a PR here to answer this question https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/815

The function names are in the graph definition (for example "func_name": "fuse_broadcast_add",) produced by nnvm compiling process. 'fuse_broadcast_add' is noting but the symbol which is part of the host library produced by nnvm compiler process.

TVM run time just does a dlopen to map func_name from graph definition to a callable function in library.

Element in op_exec is a fused operation of multiple layers some times (Ex: fuse_conv2d_broadcast_add_relu).

Siva

I have a local patch to disable operator fusing in nnvm compilation process for debugging purpose. I will upload it soon.

Roadmap for v0.2 https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/349

It has been five months a year since v0.1 release and we have made a lot of progress. I would like to propose release of v0.2 on Jan 31th.  The current checklist will go into the release note, and we will move the unfinished ones into the roadmap of next release cycle. 

Thanks everyone's effort to put in the great set of improvements.

We cannot do this actually, because the memory of previous stage will might simply get overriden by the later stages due to memory sharing optimization, only the output stage memory remains valid

How  about
Extending "Run" to allow  passing node information until which we execute and hold.

1: Now user could call run followed by get_node_output
Or
2:  get_node_output calls run internally to re run the graph up to the node requested. 


This is very helpful for us while working on new frontends and operator debug.

```
nnvm/tvm/src/codegen/llvm/codegen_cpu.cc:122,error,memleak,Memory leak: global
```
This seems not a bug. The GlobalVariable instance will be appended to the global list.
See the implementation of [GlobalVariable](http://llvm.org/doxygen/Globals_8cpp_source.html#l00307).

```
nnvm/tvm/dmlc-core/src/data.cc:31,error,memleak,Memory leak: parser
nnvm/tvm/dmlc-core/src/data.cc:46,error,memleak,Memory leak: parser
```
These two seems working properly either. Newed `parser`s are [received](https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/bf321638b22d1d33bb36775e925f7b43b22db688/src/data/parser.h#L74) by `ThreadedParser`, and are properly released in [dtor](https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/bf321638b22d1d33bb36775e925f7b43b22db688/src/data/parser.h#L86). Not sure what does the memleak checker complain about.
Let me delay this and focus us topi instead.

@clouds56 You know what, after looking at some documentation and source code, I realized that glfw already includes `gl.h` / `gl3.h` for you internally.

Could you try removing both `#include <GL/gl.h>` and `#include <OpenGL/gl3.h>`, and keep `#define GLFW_INCLUDE_GLCOREARB`, and see whether `glfw` does the right thing for you.

More specifically, could you try:

```C++
#define GLFW_INCLUDE_GLCOREARB
#include <GLFW/glfw3.h>
```

Another thing is, if `GL_STACK_OVERFLOW` and `GL_STACK_UNDERFLOW` are not present in `gl3.h`, could you just remove the case in [src/runtime/opengl/opengl_device_api.cc](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/opengl/opengl_device_api.cc), since we are not using `glPushMatrix` anyway.

Sorry I don't have a mac to test it out. Thanks!
These are better dealt with native library functions as in http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/language/extern_op.html#sphx-glr-tutorials-language-extern-op-py
Please cross check your /nnvm/tvm/topi/python/topi/math.py whether has Tanh implementation. if not you can download latest code and rerun your program again.
